Award.AwardTitle: Tunable interface properties of correlated and topological materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical and computational research, and education focused on the discovery and manipulation of materials properties and phenomena at surfaces and interfaces of recently discovered and predicted classes of insulators and superconductors, and hybrid materials and structures involving these or these in combination with strongly correlated materials. Topological insulators are insulating materials that do not conduct electricity in the bulk but are surrounded by metallic states that cover the surfaces, edges, and interfaces. Similarly topological superconductors are thought to be like ordinary superconductors in the bulk in that they conduct electricity without loss, but their surfaces and edge are enveloped in a fundamentally new quantum state of electrons with unusual properties. Hybrid structures of these materials and ones that include strongly correlated materials, that is materials where the strong interactions among electrons lead to unusual properties that arise from the correlated motion of electrons, are promising ingredients to discover new phenomena which are interesting in their own right and may form the basis of new electronic device technologies for a wide range of applications. The PI aims to build on previous work and investigate how the properties of a topological material in the boundary region at and near the surface of a topological material influence the properties of the surface states that envelope the topological material.
Some properties of strongly correlated materials are more tunable than their analogs in more conventional materials, making them interesting candidates for technological applications. However, complete understanding and control of these functionalities is an ongoing challenge. This is especially true at interfaces that form the backbone of realistic devices, in large part because the behavior of a material near a surface may differ qualitatively from that in the bulk. This award supports research that builds on the PI's previous work to connect the magnetic properties near the surfaces of topological superconductors and insulators with realistic descriptions of both bulk and surface physics. The PI will investigate hybrid devices combining superconductors, magnets, and topological electronic materials, and establish new strategies to control their properties and discover new phenomena. This award supports the discovery new materials and materials-related phenomena that contribute to the knowledgebase for future information technologies, and energy and related applications.
Research will be performed in collaboration with groups both in the US and in Europe. Developing techniques that combine theoretical and computational approaches pursued under this award will help train a new and diverse generation of students, and prepare them for a variety of careers in academia and in industry.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical and computational research, and education that is focused on surface properties of topological materials, and their interfaces with strongly correlated electron materials. A key aspect of the research is to develop a realistic description of the boundary at surfaces and interfaces and understand how the boundary affects the surface states of topological matter. Previous work shows that boundaries play an essential qualitative role in determining the magnetic properties of topological insulator surface states. Moreover, subdominant order parameter in topological superconductors can give rise to static magnetism. Building on these results, the PI will develop methods to address in detail the magnetic, spin transport, and superconducting properties of hybrid structures of topological matter with magnetic, superconducting, and other correlated electron systems. Among the crucial ingredients of the models are the absence of inversion symmetry at the interface, and its interplay with the strong spin-orbit interaction characteristic of the bulk. To make progress, the PI will combine theoretical methods of many-body physics with computational techniques. Since the magnetic properties of the surface state depend on the details of the bulk band structure, the PI will collaborate with colleagues performing first-principles calculations to make materials-specific predictions. Research performed under this award aims: to establish how to control the magnetic and spin transport properties of the topological surface states, and to achieve spin control over proximity and Josephson coupling and vice versa. These studies will advance understanding of correlated electronic matter both for applications and in search for novel quantum phenomena.
Research will be performed in collaboration with groups both in the US and in Europe. Developing techniques that combine theoretical and computational approaches pursued under this award will help train a new and diverse generation of students, and prepare them for a variety of careers in academia and in industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Topological insulators, which do not conduct electrictity in the bulk, but always have metallic state at the surfaces, are widely expected to play crucial role in next generation technological devices. Modern day devices always function by creating interfaces between different materials, and because the metallic states in topological insulators are robust not only at surfaces, but also at interfaces with magnets, superconductors, industry-standard semiconductors, and other materials. These partner materials impact their properties on the topological surfaces, aided by the fact that the magnetic moment of the electron, or spin, is fixed with respect to the direction of electron motion (its momentum). Functionality of prototype devices relies heavily on this spin-momentum locking.

The exact relative orientation of the spin and the momentum is well known experimentally and theoretically at surfaces. The driving idea behind research funded by this award is that at interfaces the nature of spin-momentum locking is different from that at surfaces, and depends on the properties of partner materials. This work aimed at understanding general principles behind specific allowed forms of spin-momentum locking, develop effective models for predicting possible outcomes, and establish a framework for computing properties of the topological interfaces from first principles in order to identify best possible partners for prototype devices.

We performed symmetry-based analysis in combination with a model microscopic calculation of the interface state between a topological insulator and a very similar, but topologically trivial, material. We identified what effect each of the symmetry classes of the potentials at the interface has on the energy and spin of the topological states. We found that in general the topological states become anisotropic, and their behavior under applied magnetic fields differs significantly from what is assumed in the literature based on the understanding of the surface states. The attached figure shows the nature of this behavior.

Since interface states are harder to probe experimentally than the surface states, we considered the consequences of this non-trivial spin-momentum locking on the measured properties. We proposed a double junction setup, shown in the image, whereby the conductance across the system oscillates as a function of gate voltage, and these oscillations contain information on the symmetry breaking at interface. We also showed that the interface potentials affect the nature of the superconductivity induced in the topological states.

In parallel we identified and implemented a scalable (to large interface unit cells) highly accurate approach to the computing the properties of the topological interfaces using density-functional-based ab initio methods. We tested it on the two of the more established members of the family of these compounds, Bi2Se3 and Bi2Te3, and obtained results that accurately describe bulk and surface structural and electronic properties on equal footing. We implemented the methodology for computing the interface states using these approaches. We are currently employing these methods for calculations of the interface properties with magnetic and semiconducting materials. 

In parallel, we pursued collaborations with experimental groups on identification of promising materials for future interfaces, and focused on superconductors and magnets without inversion center, which exhibit a  host of novel phenomena in bulk and thin film geometries. We identified a potential topological superconductors as well as a helical magnet supporting different skyrmion-like states depending on the thickness of the sample, and are still studying the possible interplay of these with topological insulators for possible devices.

In summary, the award significantly advanced our understanding of topological interfaces, which is crucial for employing topological materials in functional heterostructures and prototype devices, It laid the foundation for much of the ongoing research within the group, combining analytical and first principles based calculations to obtain a comprehensive understanding of topological phenomena at interfaces. 

The award supported graduate students, including those from underrespresented in STEM groups, and helped teach them technical, public speaking,  and analytical skills for advancing their careers. The participants were also taught general critical thinking, as well as ethical conduct of research. Taken together, these efforts enabled them to develop hard and soft skills for future success in a variety of professional settings.
